courseDescription: An examination of the historical foundations and contemporary challenges facing higher education leaders. Coursework encourages students to explore linkages between research, theory, and practice, promoting a nuanced understanding of differing perspectives on complex and evolving issues. Development of graduate-level writing is emphasized.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and addressing evolving issues in higher education

courseDescription: An overview of the student affairs function across diverse institutions, by connecting the history of higher education with contemporary issues facing student affairs professionals.  Students will spend time exploring various student affairs functions, connecting the importance of student learning and development outside the classroom.  In addition, students will explore the dynamics of student affairs organizations while identifying personal long- and short-term student affairs career goals.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and navigating the dynamics of student affairs organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Exploration and analysis of various student affairs functions
Identification and planning of personal long- and short-term student affairs career goals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the history and contemporary issues of higher education
Connecting the importance of student learning and development outside the classroom

courseDescription: This course provides the necessary knowledge and skills for administrators to both participate in and lead a strategic planning effort. Students will explore the role of strategic planning and institutional effectiveness in the context of changes in funding and demands for accountability.

The U.S. Higher Education system contains great diversity due to the inclusion of private institutions.  This course will examine the structure and organization of Higher Education in the U.S. as well as differences and similarities between private and public institutions.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of private and public institutions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of organizational hierarchies in Higher Education
Insight into leadership roles within private institutions

courseDescription: This course examines policy-in-action to help students understand how policies are developed at the organizational, state, and national levels, while gaining an understanding of the interplay of public perception and policymaking that can impact university operations. Students will explore the process by which policies are made, and they will consider why some problems are escalated to the public agenda, why some solutions are adopted and others rejected, and why some policies appear to succeed while others seem to fail.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of key issues for policy escalation
Evaluation of policy success and failure
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding policy development at various levels
Strategic decision making in policy adoption

courseTitle: Professional Helping Skills in Higher Education
courseDescription: This course explores the benefits of developing student response and support skills and how they affect the day-to-day role of a student affairs professional.  Students will work in small groups to acquire the knowledge, skills, and attitudes necessary to provide support, direction, and guidance to individuals and groups. Guest speakers currently working in student affairs roles will be featured.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Developing student response and support skills
Providing direction and guidance to individuals and groups
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and directing small group work
Collaborating with professionals in student affairs roles

courseDescription: This course examines the four key professional practices of campus internationalization: comprehensive internationalization, international student enrollment, international student and scholar services, and education abroad.  Students learn the importance of aligning internationalization on-campus through courses, curriculum, international students, and internationalization programs, all of which help to connect the institution to the changing local and global community. Guest speakers will address competencies for international educators and provide insights on functional areas in international education.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of international student enrollment procedures
Familiarity with international student and scholar services
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate with diverse international students and scholars
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Aligning internationalization efforts with local and global communities
Ability to analyze and apply insights from guest speakers
Assessing the effectiveness of internationalization programs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating internationalization efforts across courses and curriculum
Fostering connections between the institution and the local and global community

courseTitle: Global Higher Education Systems: A Comparative Approach
courseDescription: An examination of the development of the three primary systems of higher education in the world today: the U.S., British and European (Continental) systems. The course will also examine, as appropriate, other systems of higher education from around the world. A study abroad component is required, for which additional costs will apply.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and analyzing trends in global higher education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing study abroad components

courseDescription: A survey of college student experiences, with an emphasis on growth and development. Coursework will encourage students to apply theory to practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying theoretical knowledge in practical scenarios
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and understanding college student experiences
Critical thinking to apply theory to practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership through personal growth and development

courseDescription: An exploration of the legal issues facing higher education in the United States. Topics to be discussed include the foundations from which higher education law emerges, current case law, state and federal statutory law, and contract law, as well as risk management and liability issues. Students may have the opportunity to visit the Supreme Court and to view oral arguments. Additionally, the course will address the ethical issues faced when shaping and implementing institutional policy, curriculum, and procedures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of state and federal statutory law
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Observation and interpretation of oral arguments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of current case law

courseDescription: This course examines the budget process in colleges and universities, as well as the impact of budget activities on all areas of planning and operations within an institution. It will cover elements of educational finance, including budgeting and resource management, with a focus on process and environmental factors that affect how institutions operate. Students will develop and enhance their abilities to write and speak effectively about finance-related issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of environmental factors affecting institutional operation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective written communication on finance-related issues
Effective oral communication on finance-related issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing budget activities and their impact on planning and operations
Understanding and analyzing the budget process in educational institutions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and operational management within an institution
Understanding and application of budgeting processes

courseDescription: This course provides students with skills to design educational experiences, plan educational programs, and conduct research on a variety of teaching and learning-related questions. Participants will consider the meaning of learning and the various contextual factors that influence the learning process in higher education, as well as the application of the learning sciences to the design of learning environments. Students will focus on creating inclusive, diverse, and equitable educational environments and use their insights to improve the practices through assessment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research in teaching and learning-related topics
Application of learning sciences in learning environment design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Creating inclusive, diverse, and equitable educational environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing contextual factors influencing learning process
Assessing effectiveness of teaching and learning strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading the design of inclusive and diverse learning environments

courseDescription: This course provides students with the basic theory, knowledge and skills needed to be an effective leader within higher education institutions. Classes are designed for those who intend to pursue careers as higher education practitioners. Course assignments will take a practical approach to applying theoretical principles and identifying students' personal leadership styles.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within higher education institutions
Adapting leadership style to various situations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical principles to practical situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Knowledge and skills for effective leadership in higher education

courseDescription: The culminating experience for the master's degree, intended to integrate and apply the knowledge gained in the degree program to complex issues regarding policy and practice in higher education. Groups of students address a real world problem currently faced by a department or unit on campus and work on comprehensive portfolios.

An exploration of institutional advancement in the areas of institutional marketing, event management, campaign development, social media, donor identification and cultivation, planned giving, corporate partnership development, and foundation management.

This course provides a thorough analysis and dissection of a rotating, current issue in higher education, covering a broad range of higher education administrative areas. For each issue, students will examine relevant benchmark law, contemporary issues, historical perspectives, political realities, institutional missions and cultures, ethical considerations, leadership and management approaches, and courses of action available to decision-makers.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and presentation of contemporary issues

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide greater understanding of the leadership role of college and university presidents and the multiplex of issues associated with the office of the presidency at the various types of American institutions.  The course will utilize case study analysis, guest presentation, and review of the literature.  There will be rigorous discussion, readings, and analyses in a collegial and reciprocal learning environment.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Knowledge of higher education institution structures

courseDescription: An advanced seminar emphasizing the historical, philosophical, and institutional analyses of the development and status of adult and continuing education within the higher education community.

The University advisor and site supervisor work together with students to develop and implement a set of objectives intended to familiarize them with the operation of an administrative area within an institution of higher education, to assist them in acquiring the practical skills necessary for the operation of that office, and to develop skills that are transferable to other administrative areas.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Liaising between university advisor and site supervisor
Effective communication in an administrative setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing and implementing office operational objectives

courseTitle: External and Internal Relations for Higher Education
courseDescription: This course serves as an introduction for prospective and current administrators to the social and political context of the higher education environment and its various constituencies.  It will teach them to recognize the impact of politics, socioeconomic situations, diversity, media, monetary issues, and equity issues on their leadership practices.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of higher education environment and its various constituencies
Knowledge of socioeconomic situations and their impact
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing socioeconomic situations and their impact
Understanding and responding to political scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in diverse and socioeconomic situations

courseTitle: Global and Intercultural Perspectives in Higher Education
courseDescription: This course explores global and intercultural issues for higher education leaders. Students examine issues encountered by student affairs and higher education professionals from global and intercultural perspectives, including program design and evaluation, partnerships between individuals and organizations worldwide, and budgeting and staff management. The course will prepare students with knowledge and skills that can be used to promote internationally-oriented practice, professional dialogue, and research.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Navigating partnerships between individuals and organizations worldwide
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research in global and intercultural perspectives

courseDescription: An examination of the history of higher education and its connection to current higher education events. The course provides an understanding of the foundations of higher education, including European influences, societal forces, and economic factors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using digital platforms for historical research

courseTitle: Governance, Organization, and Administration of Higher Education
courseDescription: An exploration of how organizational structures, behavior, culture, and context influence institutional governance and administration. In-class activities examine the approaches institutions use in decision-making. Through discussion of assigned readings, current events, and guest lectures, students learn how institutions govern themselves and the effects of various governance practices. Case studies, role playing, and active discussion allow students to apply theoretical perspectives to the practical workings of higher education administration.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of institutional governance practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of theoretical perspectives to practical problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Application of cultural and contextual understanding to administration

courseDescription: Study of selected topics in higher education administration.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with faculty and staff
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills for managing administrative tasks
Strategic planning for higher education institutions

courseDescription: Independent study of special topics in higher education for master's students.

Explores issues of contemporary concern among practitioner-scholars in American higher education. The course utilizes a historical perspective to establish the background for the discussion of the issues influencing higher education today. Coursework and readings provide a nuanced understanding of differing perspectives on complex issues. Research and professional practice are examined through an issues based format that challenges students to develop and support their perspectives on the issues discussed. Doctoral-level writing is emphasized.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Development and articulation of personal perspective

courseDescription: An examination of the historical foundations and contemporary challenges facing higher education leaders. Coursework encourages students to explore linkages between research, theory, and practice, promoting a nuanced understanding of differing perspectives on complex and evolving issues. Development of graduate-level writing is emphasized.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of complex and evolving issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding historical foundations and contemporary challenges in higher education
Exploration and integration of research, theory, and practice

courseDescription: This course is designed to be taken in three parts throughout the program. It provides information on the doctoral process to help students successfully navigate their programs. It helps doctoral students enhance their abilities to search the scholarly literature; narrow their research topics; and improve their critical reading and inquiry, critical thinking and analysis, and writing. It focuses on approaches to scholarly writing in the field, strategies for inviting and providing peer review and feedback, and skills useful in analytical reading of scholarly work.

An overview of the student affairs function across diverse institutions, by connecting the history of higher education with contemporary issues facing student affairs professionals.  Students will spend time exploring various student affairs functions, connecting the importance of student learning and development outside the classroom.  In addition, students will explore the dynamics of student affairs organizations while identifying personal long- and short-term student affairs career goals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of historical and contemporary issues in higher education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within student affairs organizations
Building relationships with diverse student populations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing student learning and development needs
Addressing contemporary issues facing student affairs professionals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning and development in relation to student affairs
Understanding and applying student development theories

courseDescription: This course provides the necessary knowledge and skills for administrators both to participate in and lead a meaningful strategic planning effort. Students will explore the role of strategic planning and institutional effectiveness in the context of changes in funding and demands for accountability.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of measurements and metrics for institutional effectiveness

courseDescription: The U.S. Higher Education system contains great diversity due to the inclusion of private institutions.  This course will examine the structure and organization of Higher Education in the U.S. as well as differences and similarities between private and public institutions.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of organizational structures in education

Students will explore the process by which policies are made, and they will consider why some problems are escalated to the public agenda, why some solutions are adopted and others rejected, and why some policies appear to succeed while others seem to fail.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of political processes in an educational context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of policy success and failure
Escalating problems to the public agenda

Strategic decision making in policy adoption and rejection

Students will work in small groups to acquire the knowledge, skills, and attitudes necessary to provide support, direction, and guidance to individuals and groups. Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying student affairs protocols

Organizing and leading small group activities

Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of international student enrollment processes

Evaluating the effectiveness of international education programs

courseDescription: Independent study of special topics in higher education for doctoral students.
Work on dissertation under the direction of dissertation chair.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after advancement to candidacy. All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Maintaining active status in doctoral program
